data.Difference between Base Properties and A:
ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation,
Durability) is a set of properties that
guarantee the integrity and consistency of
data in a traditional database.
data.Col1:
The BASE properties are a more relaxed
version of ACID that trade off some
consistency guarantees for greater
scalability and availability.

data.Difference between Base Properties and A:
The primary difference between the two is
that ACID requires immediate consistency,
data.Col1:
while BASE only requires eventual
consistency.

data.Difference between Base Properties and A:
ACID is better suited to traditional
transactional databases.
data.Col1:
The BASE is more suitable for use in
large-scale, highly-available systems,

columns: Difference between Base Properties and ACID Properties
